step1_initial_points.title: Uncertainty in AI Market Landscape
step1_initial_points.description: The department is in an exploratory phase, lacking a clear understanding of the AI tools, solutions, and services available and relevant to government functions, which hinders strategic planning and procurement.

step1_initial_points.title: Risk of Regulatory & Security Non-Compliance
step1_initial_points.description: Ensuring any adopted AI tool strictly adheres to government ICT, security, cyber, and privacy policies (e.g., SA IPPs) is a critical requirement and a significant challenge, creating a high compliance burden.

step1_initial_points.title: Integration with Existing Government Systems
step1_initial_points.description: There is a significant concern about the maturity, scalability, and adaptability of new AI solutions and their ability to integrate smoothly with existing, potentially complex government IT infrastructure.

step1_initial_points.title: Budgeting and Costing for AI Initiatives
step1_initial_points.description: Lacking indicative costing and clear pricing models for AI solutions makes it difficult to conduct procurement planning, allocate budgets, and estimate the total cost of ownership for future AI projects.

step1_initial_points.title: Safeguarding Data with Third-Party LLMs
step1_initial_points.description: A specific and acute concern exists around how AI solutions, particularly those using third-party large language models (LLMs), will ensure the security and safeguarding of sensitive government data.

step1_initial_points.title: Need to Improve Efficiency & Service Delivery
step1_initial_points.description: Current government operations require a boost in efficiency, decision-making, and innovation. There's a need for AI tools to improve service delivery, public satisfaction, and community outcomes.

step1_initial_points.title: Mitigating Risk of Large-Scale Adoption
step1_initial_points.description: The government is hesitant to commit to major AI deployments without first de-risking the investment. There's a preference for pilots and collaborations to trial solutions in real-world scenarios.

step1_initial_points.title: Lack of In-House AI Implementation Experience
step1_initial_points.description: The department lacks deep experience in deploying AI solutions and needs to learn from vendors' 'lessons learned' and best practices from similar government contexts to ensure success.

step1_initial_points.title: Addressing Workforce Skills Gap for AI Tools
step1_initial_points.description: There is an implicit concern that staff will require training to use new AI tools effectively, indicating a potential skills gap that could hinder user adoption and the realization of benefits.
